positive.review:
Initially, when I first saw this game and played it. It was quite boring to be blunt. Basic, turn your brain off game where you collect unique objects to sell. 

I picked it up again after years of not touching it. I wanted to 100% it. To pay tribute to someone I really care about, who is now gone from my life. 

I started to read the letters and lore. Nearing the end of the game, I got very uncomfortable. The letters, the soundtrack, everything started to make me really, really uncomfortable. I started to reminisce a lot, but I pushed through. I then got to the last letter of the game. Where the credits began to play. 

I cried, a lot. The irony begins when I learned the game is about closure and being okay with letting go. Small spoilers from here on. 

You leave an unresolved past behind, one that you shared with someone you deeply cared about. The letters represent the memories that tend to arrive at a delay. The lore capsules all around the world tell a story of someone who gave up their big dream to stay with the one they loved. You are the opposite, you follow your dreams, a dream that your relationship no longer aligns with. The glass desert represents that part of you that hurts and needs extra attention to heal. It made me uncomfortable because that was its design, its the ruin of a bittersweet past.

This is a beautiful story told through a game with a silly face. It tells you it's okay. It's okay to let go and let your paths separate. You can love someone enough to stop holding them in place. You can still love them from a distance. Even if it feels like they're a thousand light years away.

Slime Rancher is a YouTube classic, I distinctly remember its boom of popularity being far more wholesome than the others at the time, and it's still a pack of that wholesomeness.
   It's really hard to describe, but somehow the game manages to make walking around the same areas multiple times fun, because this time you have a goal, and the next time you go through, that goal is different. Sometimes you're going in to get slimes, sometimes to collect resources and make money, and sometimes to collect secret items. Although it sounds simple, it's weirdly engaging, as you have to take care of the slimes in your ranch as well, getting upgrades for them and yourself.
   How the game makes those upgrades important is by starting you out with very few options and cash, giving you a goal right from the get-go: Make your own life easier. Be with more sprinting time, more storage, or even means of defense. I think the overall gameplay and item-gathering is superior to its sequel. It's way less greedy and grindy, and you can get what you're going for way faster.
   Now I'll stop being vague and talk about the environments: First you have the Dry Reef, simple slimes, simple shore beach with some plateaus, perfect to begin. The Indigo Quarry introduces you to more dangerous slimes, water, and risky jumps. The Moss Blanket loves its aggressive slimes, and is very intricate on how to find the secret items. The Ancient Ruins is a maze that is fulfilling to solve, and the Glass Desert, well, it really is the final area and isn't afraid of you knowing. You'll spend a lot of time on these, as well as the extra areas that were added later with updates. They are all great, extremely memorable, and without a single bad or unforgiving place.
   Ranching-wise, it's okay, it has methods of automation which is always good, but it's not complex, and that might appeal to some. If you like decorating though, there's a lot to choose from, but they need resources that might be better off used in upgrades.
   The graphics were also not much at the time and is now also overshadowed by Slime Rancher 2, but it's not bad to look at, and the style itself is on point. The music is fantastic, you don't get tired of it, and it fits the wonder of exploration very well.
   This game is easy, you're only going to die if you fall accidentally, but some puzzles may take time figuring out. Replay value: absolutely. Achievements and secrets: yeah, you're going to need a guide.
   Not much else to say besides the fact that the vibe this game gives is great and might really cheer you up. It may be old now but it's still gold.

Second time playing through, I got to the Glass Desert again (10 hours in) and I got hit by the same feeling that had me drop the game 6 years ago:

The game has limited automation and it often feels like it actively hinders automation, so much of the game is just busywork what with the limited hotbar and item-stacks. It's just annoying and hard to enjoy the game knowing that the ranch is falling apart if you're not constantly doing busywork to keep the slimes fed. 

Money is also worthless by the mid-game, I don't even have a purpose in playing now except to speed through to the ending. But that's not enough justification to care to keep playing it, it's too annoying to keep sinking hours in to this trying to combat the poor end-game or near-end-game design choices stacking up.

I cracked this game many, many years ago but never played it the "correct" way, which brought me to buying the game some days ago.
Initially fun, but with each hour spend it progressively gets more grindy, filled with extreme amounts of backtracking. You want to remove the backtracking? Grind insane amounts of resources for two teleporters. 
Grinding, backtracking, grinding backtracking.
After around 6 hours I've basically seen like 80-90% of the game and because of the stuff the game expects me to do right now I definitely don't feel like continuing.
I wish I'd enjoy it more, maybe the second game is better in that regard.

Its exciting when you first start playing and its fun in the first couple of hours but after that its just repeating the same stuff. Go out for food, explore the same locations over and over again, get keys sell plorts. Gameplay stays the same through the entire game with small changes. If you want it then buy it but its not that good like people on social medias say.

Slow, boring, grindier in the end game than some roblox tycoons I've played. It's just overall not a very good feedback loop and I think people glazing this game just don't play very many games like it.
